Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the age of the shark by stating it is 392 years old, while the study only estimated it to be between 272-512 years old.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as the exact age of the shark has not been verified.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the shark was discovered recently, but the photo was taken during a 2016 study.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the age of the shark, such as other factors that could affect the radiocarbon dating results.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the researcher who took the photo stated that the age of the shark has not been verified.
Understate: The claim understates the uncertainty surrounding the age of the shark by presenting a specific age (392 years) instead of the range provided by the study.
